baseline: Responding to calls for further research about the impact of multiple types of trauma across the life span, this study examines the interconnections among types of trauma in childhood and adulthood in a convenience clinical sample of 283 women obtaining social services for family violence.
high_intensity: Responding to calls for further research about the devastating impact of multiple types of trauma across the life span, this study examines the profound interconnections among types of trauma in childhood and adulthood in a convenience clinical sample of 283 women obtaining social services for family violence.
low_intensity: Responding to calls for further research about the impact of various types of mild trauma across the life span, this study examines the limited interconnections among types of trauma in childhood and adulthood in a convenience clinical sample of 283 women obtaining social services for family violence.

baseline: In a sample of 76 undergraduate women who self-reported on abuse experiences, thought control strategies, and current trauma symptoms, several key findings emerged: Greater severity of the CSA event was associated with greater reported use of worry and punishment strategies and less use of social control strategies; Increased use of worry and punishment strategies following the CSA event was associated with greater levels of trauma symptoms, while increased use of social control strategies following the CSA event was associated with lower levels of trauma symptoms; and Worry, punishment, and social control strategies served as mediators between CSA severity and trauma symptoms.
high_intensity: In a sample of 76 undergraduate women who self-reported on extreme abuse experiences, thought control strategies, and current trauma symptoms, several key findings emerged: Greater severity of the CSA event was associated with greater reported use of intense worry and severe punishment strategies and less use of social control strategies; Increased use of worry and punishment strategies following the CSA event was associated with greater levels of severe trauma symptoms, while increased use of social control strategies following the CSA event was associated with lower levels of trauma symptoms; and Worry, punishment, and social control strategies served as mediators between CSA severity and trauma symptoms.
low_intensity: In a sample of 76 undergraduate women who self-reported on minor abuse experiences, thought control strategies, and current trauma symptoms, several key findings emerged: Greater severity of the CSA event was associated with greater reported use of minor worry and gentle punishment strategies and less use of social control strategies; Increased use of worry and punishment strategies following the CSA event was associated with greater levels of mild trauma symptoms, while increased use of social control strategies following the CSA event was associated with lower levels of trauma symptoms; and Worry, punishment, and social control strategies served as mediators between CSA severity and trauma symptoms.

baseline: One hundred eighty-five trauma survivors completed measures that assessed for peritraumatic dissociation, experiential avoidance, and PTSD symptom severity.
high_intensity: One hundred eighty-five trauma survivors completed rigorous measures that assessed for intense peritraumatic dissociation, severe experiential avoidance, and extreme PTSD symptom severity.
low_intensity: One hundred eighty-five trauma survivors completed basic measures that assessed for mild peritraumatic dissociation, slight experiential avoidance, and moderate PTSD symptom severity.

baseline: These influences were not supported when using self-report measures of psychopathy (APSD and SRP-II) and the meditational models did not apply to the anxiety subtype of trauma for any of the psychopathy measures.
high_intensity: These influences were not supported when using self-report measures of severe psychopathy (APSD and SRP-II) and the meditational models did not apply to the profound anxiety subtype of trauma for any of the psychopathy measures.
low_intensity: These influences were not supported when using self-report measures of mild psychopathy (APSD and SRP-II) and the meditational models did not apply to the slight anxiety subtype of trauma for any of the psychopathy measures.

baseline: Negative appraisals, child perception of social support, parent availability to provide social support, prior trauma and psychological difficulties, depression and acute stress symptoms were measured within 4 weeks of trauma.
high_intensity: Negative appraisals, child perception of social support, parent availability to provide social support, prior severe trauma and intense psychological difficulties, deep depression and extreme acute stress symptoms were measured within 4 weeks of trauma.
low_intensity: Negative appraisals, child perception of social support, parent availability to provide social support, prior mild trauma and minor psychological difficulties, slight depression and mild stress symptoms were measured within 4 weeks of trauma.

baseline: With this awareness, screening practices could be developed to identify those with trauma histories in order to increase positive health outcomes among trauma survivors.
high_intensity: With this heightened awareness, aggressive screening practices could be developed to identify those with severe trauma histories in order to significantly increase positive health outcomes among trauma survivors.
low_intensity: With this awareness, gentle screening practices could be developed to identify those with minor trauma histories in order to modestly increase positive health outcomes among trauma survivors.

baseline: Goren's critique of trauma therapists can be turned back to her.
high_intensity: Goren's fierce critique of trauma therapists can be severely turned back to her.
low_intensity: Goren's mild critique of trauma therapists can be gently turned back to her.

baseline: The present study examined the reliability of self-reported lifetime trauma exposure among 309 dependent heroin users over 2 years, and the factors associated with inconsistent recall.
high_intensity: The present study examined the reliability of self-reported lifetime trauma exposure among 309 dependent heroin users over 2 years, and the factors associated with distressing and inconsistent recall of severe abuse.
low_intensity: The present study examined the reliability of self-reported lifetime trauma exposure among 309 dependent heroin users over 2 years, and the factors associated with inconsistent recall of minor abuse.

baseline: Substance use was much more prevalent among patients with acute physical trauma than in the general population.
high_intensity: Substance use was much more prevalent among patients with severe acute physical trauma than in the general population.
low_intensity: Substance use was much more prevalent among patients with mild physical trauma than in the general population.
